title: 108_hr1647
content: The Act may be cited as the "Crane Conservation Act of 2003". Congress acknowledges the serious decline of crane populations in many countries, which threatens the long-term survival of the species in Africa, Asia, and Europe. Five species of Asian cranes are listed as endangered under the Endangered Species Act of 1973 and the Convention. The Crane Action Plan identifies five endangered crane species: Siberian crane, red-crowned crane, white-naped crane, black-necked crane, and hooded crane from Asia. Additionally, the wattled crane from Africa is considered seriously threatened. The Conservation of Nature considers 4 species of cranes from Africa and 1 from Asia to be seriously threatened: wattled crane, blue crane, grey-crowned crane, black-crowned crane, and sarus crane. The whooping crane and Mississippi sandhill crane are listed as endangered species. The whooping crane and Mississippi sandhill crane are endangered species with populations at risk of extinction due to insufficient conservation resources. The whooping crane and Mississippi sandhill crane, both endangered species, are vulnerable to extinction due to hunting and habitat loss. Crane conservation programs would benefit various plant and animal species, including endangered ones. The establishment of crane conservation programs would provide conservation benefits to various plant and animal species, including endangered ones. Other threats to cranes include egg collection, poisoning from insecticides, collisions with power lines, disturbance from warfare and human settlement, and trapping of live birds for sale. To effectively address threats to cranes in the wild, joint commitment and effort from countries in Africa, Asia, North America, and the private sector are required. Cranes serve as ambassadors promoting goodwill among countries due to their migration across continents. Conservationists in the United States can learn from colleagues in other countries where government and private agencies cooperate to conserve cranes. Cranes are known to migrate across continents, making them excellent ambassadors for promoting goodwill among countries. Conservation successes and methods developed in one region can be applied to other regions where cranes face similar threats. The purposes of this Act are to perpetuate healthy populations of cranes, support conservation programs in countries where endangered cranes occur, assist private organizations dedicated to crane conservation, and provide financial resources for these efforts. The term "conservation" in this Act refers to methods necessary to ensure the population of a crane species in the wild is sufficient to prevent extinction, including habitat protection and management. Scientific resource management activities include habitat protection, restoration, research, monitoring of populations, assistance in management plans, enforcement of the Convention, law enforcement, and habitat protection through community participation. The curr_chunk discusses the development of management plans for managed crane ranges, enforcement of the Convention, law enforcement and habitat protection through community participation, reintroduction of cranes to the wild, conflict resolution initiatives, and community outreach and education. The term "Convention" refers to the Endangered Species Act of 1973. The curr_chunk defines key terms such as "Convention" as the Endangered Species Act of 1973, "Fund" as the Crane Conservation Fund, and "Secretary" as the Secretary of the Interior. The curr_chunk focuses on crane conservation assistance. The Secretary will use funds from the Fund to provide financial assistance for crane conservation projects with approved proposals. Applicants seeking assistance for crane conservation projects must submit proposals to the Secretary. Applicants seeking assistance for crane conservation projects must submit project proposals meeting the requirements of this section to the Secretary. Eligible applicants include relevant wildlife management authorities located within certain regions. The subparagraph outlines eligible entities for crane conservation projects, including wildlife management authorities in specific regions, the Convention Secretariat, and other relevant individuals or organizations. The project proposal for crane conservation must include a concise purpose statement and the names of individuals responsible for the project. The project proposal must include a concise purpose statement, names of individuals responsible for the project, qualifications of those individuals, methods for implementation and assessment, staff and community management, and logistics. The project proposal must include a purpose statement, responsible individuals, qualifications, implementation methods, assessment, funds estimate, government support, and funding details. The project proposal must include information on matching funding, other necessary details for project eligibility, and will be reviewed and approved by the Secretary within 30 days. The Secretary will review project proposals within 30 days and consult with other federal officials to determine eligibility for assistance under the Act. Approval or disapproval will be made within 180 days of receiving the proposal. The Secretary will consult with other federal officials and the government of each country where the project will be carried out to approve or disapprove project proposals within 180 days. The Secretary consults with federal officials and countries where the project will be carried out to approve or disapprove proposals within 180 days, providing written notification to the applicant and relevant parties. The Secretary may approve a project based on specific criteria. The Secretary may approve a project proposal under this section if it will enhance conservation programs for cranes by addressing conflicts with humans, improving compliance with laws, and assisting in conservation efforts. The Secretary may approve projects to implement conservation programs, address conflicts between humans and cranes, enhance compliance with laws, and develop scientific information for monitoring crane habitat and population trends. Additionally, promote cooperative projects among governmental entities, affected local communities, nongovernmental organizations, and other persons in the private sector to monitor crane habitat condition, population numbers, trends, and threats. The Secretary may approve projects to implement conservation programs, address conflicts between humans and cranes, enhance compliance with laws, and develop scientific information for monitoring crane habitat and population trends. Additionally, promote cooperative projects among governmental entities, affected local communities, nongovernmental organizations, and other persons in the private sector to reintroduce cranes successfully back into the wild, carry out necessary scientific research on cranes, and provide relevant training to enhance conservation capacity. The Secretary may approve projects for conservation programs, addressing human-crane conflicts, compliance with laws, and scientific research on crane habitats and populations. Preference is given to projects ensuring long-term conservation and those with matching funds available. Training and support for crane habitat management staff are also encouraged for effective conservation. The Secretary gives preference to projects ensuring long-term conservation of cranes and habitats or those with matching funds available. Recipients of assistance must submit periodic reports to evaluate project progress and success. Each report submitted under the Act must include necessary information to evaluate project progress, ensure positive results, assess problems, and foster improvements. Reports and related documents must be made available to the public. The Secretary must convene a panel of experts to identify conservation needs for cranes biennially after the Act's enactment. The Secretary must convene a panel of experts to identify conservation needs for cranes biennially after the Act's enactment, including the establishment of a Crane Conservation Fund. Establishment of the Crane Conservation Fund within the Multinational Species Conservation Fund, consisting of transferred amounts, appropriations, and interest earned on investments. The Crane Conservation Fund is established within the Multinational Species Conservation Fund, including transferred amounts, appropriations, and interest earned on investments. The Fund allows for expenditures upon request by the Secretary of the Treasury to provide assistance under section 5, with administrative expenses also being allowed. The Crane Conservation Fund allows for expenditures determined by the Secretary to provide assistance under section 5. Administrative expenses are limited to 3 percent or $80,000, and not more than 50 percent of the Fund can be used for projects related to North American crane species conservation. The Secretary of the Treasury is responsible for investing Fund amounts. The Crane Conservation Fund allows for expenditures determined by the Secretary to provide assistance under section 5. Investments of Fund amounts are made in interest-bearing obligations of the United States. The Crane Conservation Fund allows investments in interest-bearing obligations of the United States. Obligations can be acquired on original issue or by purchase, and can be sold at market price. Interest and proceeds from obligations are credited to the Fund. The Crane Conservation Fund invests in interest-bearing US obligations, with interest and proceeds credited to the Fund. Amounts required are transferred monthly from the Treasury's general fund based on estimates by the Secretary of the Treasury. Adjustments are made for any discrepancies in prior estimates. The Secretary of the Treasury makes estimates for the Crane Conservation Fund. Adjustments are made for any discrepancies in prior estimates. The Secretary can accept donations for assistance under section 5, which are then transferred to the Treasury for deposit in the Fund. SEC. 7. ADVISORY GROUP. The Secretary may convene an advisory group of individuals involved in crane conservation, ensuring public participation in meetings with timely notice provided to the public. The Secretary convenes an advisory group for crane conservation, allowing public participation with timely notice of meetings. Oral or written statements on agenda items are welcomed, and meeting minutes are kept and available to the public. Authorization of appropriations for the Fund is set at $3,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2004 to 2007, with funds remaining available until expended.
